comments.commentBody: Kurt -- a skeptic would see error bars on predictions in both directions. Virtually everyone who complains about the study of climate only sees the error bars going in one direction. Only in one. Assymetry like that is not skepticism or thought, but ideology backed by argument. And the disturbing discrepancy in predictions is much more in impacts appearing earlier than expected. (And it would be great to get a DotEarth review of this, as several areas, like ice melt, seem to be decades ahead of schedule.)

Gun pushers and climate change denialists are equally adamant that they alone are free of confirmation bias.

Once can see that pervasive public mental illness characterizes the lead-up to all major social collapses.

RR:

On error bars. Since predictions of Global Mean Atmospheric Surface Temperature have clearly been running high (applicable error bars are those on the low end), why would someone seeking the truth focus on the yet further reality-challenged upper error bars from climate models?

Kurt in Switzerland

The excerpt reads like a "how to" for confirmation bias. Since overall from the mid-19th C until the present, CO2 emissions and CO2 concentration have risen AND since mean atmospheric temperature has also risen, glaciers have receded, etc., there is general correlation between the two. The ice core record shows correlation as well, albeit with CO2 lagging temperature.

The claim that we have choices (to mitigate the human emissions of carbon dioxide, thereby measurably affecting the Keeling Curve - CO2 concentration over time) actually hasn't ever been shown to be valid.

To stretch that further and claim that [Climate Science] is sufficiently well-developed to make useful predictions for the future (based on human GHG emissions and/or atmospheric GHG concentration) is just silly.

That is why there are sceptics. Who actually look at the predictions and compare with the actuals. And point out the discrepancy (which, sadly for the discipline, is growing).

Kurt in Switzerland

"Thank you Mr. Wong for the China dimension; now, to balance the account, I should like The Times to examine US activities. Problem: NYT does not seek balance, and rather gives Obama favored treatment; how compare China's record with the present massive surveillance of NSA?"

NY Times with the help of Mr. Snowden has been quite prolific in exposing US activities.

Now if Mr. Snowden or others could expose the surveillance efforts of China, then we could compare the efforts of the two countries.

It could be that the Chinese at this point don't lack the desire but do lack the technology.

I too love history. While I was in school, and this includes college I never read a history text that was interesting to read.  Why is this so?  Perhaps the problem is trying to present two or more sides, an attempt to be fair.  When teaching science or engineering, there is no attempt to be fair.  The standard is to be right.  I think it's possible to be right about history.
Speaking of simplistic myth making, don't liberals believe that America, especially American whites (gasp!) are the root of all evil?
History, like beauty, is in the eye of the beholder.

A related serious problem is that those who do "know history" actually know self-serving myths. They then reason by analogy from their myths, to get answers they like for current events.

Their myth never happened. It is not reality. It is just an excuse to do what they prefer to do today.

Some write popular history. Some write revisionist history. Some write official history as received from the propagandists of the winning side. None are "history" from which any valid lesson can be gained.

High school history in my experience was all myth. It was less than useful, actually dangerous. A thinking person who "learns" it will come to very wrong answers, and must unlearn it before learning anything real to get to real answers.

I love history. I encourage its study. I do NOT favor pushing simplistic myth to bored young people. That is something else entirely, leading to only bad ends.
It's a shame that you're missing the political underpinnings of the Republican movement in Ireland. To those who understand the situation there, your comments do provide some chuckles.

Andyreid has hit the nail squarely on the head.  Loss of jobs, despair, poverty have always been the underlying cause of social and political unrest.  Many thought that the economic reforms of the Roosevelt era and the rise of a united Europe after WWII would last.  Alas, the tide that lifted all the boats proved insufficient.  Greed, all-encompassing greed, the bete-noir of humanity has won yet again as it has for all the centuries who histories are known.

So true. I doubt Boko Harim would have
come about, if the Pres. of Nigeria, whomever,
for so long, had distributed Shell oil wealth
evenly across the country.

Religious fanatics and mercenaries are paid
by 'supporting' countries to spread problems
when a nation appears to have those internal
messes.

The more robots for manufacturing with attendant unemployment are a sure way for
population-expanding countries like Nigeria to foment problems.

About six years ago I was in a trip to Dublin, before everything collapsed financially. Both Dublin and Belfast was booming housing-wise, etc. We asked our cab driver if Ireland had any interest in reuniting with Northern Ireland and his response was "why would we want the headaches involved."

The reality was and is that if the economy thrives and people can get ahead these problems don't exist. The IRA collapsed when their members got jobs and became apart of society.

The poverty of the 1980's created the skinheads in the UK, the IRA while it goes back further still is nothing but a product of poverty. The National Front in France only has success has been because of lost jobs, blamed on foreign immigrants while it is really the off shoring of jobs by major corporations.

The devil makes use of idle hands, while unemployment seems to be a taken for granted these days it is the real root to these problems. The oligarchs would have us return to the days of Charles Dickens and debtors prisons when the real reason for all of these problems is a lack of jobs and people trying to find a purpose in life with a system that doesn't care about anyone except billionaires.
If trends continue, we are headed the way of Europe, i.e. a loose confederation of groups of states along ideological lines.

I would argue that there is very little cohesion amongst the states any longer. CA, OR, WA may have lots in common with each other. But these 3 states share little in the way of economy, culture, etc with the stes of the former confederacy. And those people in the confederacy? They resent and even hate people from other states. Our current leadership vacuum is fueled by this disconnect between our states.

Senator J. William Fulbright wrote a book on the Arrogance of Power, 1966

"If America has a service to perform in the world_and I believe it has_it is in large part the service of its own example. In our excessive involvement in the affairs of other countries, we are not only living off our assets and denying our own people the proper enjoyment of their resources; we are also denying the world the example of a free society enjoying its freedom to the fullest. This is regrettable indeed for a nation that aspires to teach democracy to other nations, because, as Burke said! 'E xample is the school of mankind, and they will learn at no other.' . . ."

As I see it, the primary problem is Nationalism. After WWII the leaders of Western Europe got together to try and prevent the continuation of ongoing wars that were the history of Europe.

The task was to unify them to a common cause, to stop the constant intrusions into each others territory for some supposed aggression by the other country.

Two ways to do this was to make open borders, and a common currency. The open border is widely accepted. You no longer have to stop at every border and show your papers. The idea is that everyone is a citizen of Europe.

But the problem of national identity remains. Unlike the U.S. where we do have differences between the states, they are all governed by a common law, the Constitution, the European Union is not a union of states, but of individual countries, with their own laws, languages and customs. We have a common language, they do not. The citizens of the various countries do not want to follow the laws of the other countries.

For instance the countries that are weaker economically resent the Germans, who are very conservative with their money. other countries do not want to beheld to their austerity. The extremists are the same as the the Tea Party here, they want things the way they were in the last century, the want to take back their imagined superiority. Many of them re still holding a grudge against Germany, which is the most stable state. Getting them to all agree is a Herculean task.

AND please - as somebody who has relatives in five European countries -(and the US) - this is a very sad and sorrow post - because it (again) doesn't focus on the real issue.

Or - as another commenter already has mentioned: In Europe - and to a much, much bigger extent in the US - INEQUALITY is destroying societies - and in another twist of bitter irony - a lot of what dear Prof. calls 'Eurocrats' are fighting this destruction -(at least the Eurocrats on the left!) - and that a liberal economist is unable to see that - is truly sad and dissapointing!
Should a nation's foreign policy be based only on all of the citizens' selfish interests?
Well, darn, Martin.
Welcome back, in any case.

Are you still in midtown Manhattan? Somewhat congested, as it's Fleet Week, but not nearly as bad as the eight days of unalloyed horror that was Super Bowl Boulevard.

http://tinyurl.com/pgk9cb5
I posted as well.  Maybe it will appear eventually.  But I'm not redoing it if not.

America believes it is morally superior to Europe as does Europe to America.    In fact it seems that it is a large part of the human condition to believe in our personal moral superiority.  We all come from the same roots as human beings.  But our stubbornness to hold onto positions despite evidence that proves those positions harmful comes from our desire to prove ourselves superior.  Our wars, economic and environmental crises as well as much  of our poverty is born within our desire to be right at the expense of everything else.  Economic systems become divorced from the needs of people.  Illusion becomes the norm  And how to take humane action is lost.  My belief is that there is enough for everyone, but that  our lack of wisdom and greed corrupts our ability to humanely share our wealth.  Perhaps this seems off the target  of the European economic situation, but we all share  in our common humanity. To paraphrase, the answer lies not in our stars, but in ourselves.
Was LD's play at the Gold Cup not of WC team quality or is he playing noticeably worse now?

This is a really good group? Sure, but not nearly as good as it would be with Donovan in it.

Klinsmann has done his job? Not sure about that. Please explain how Yedlin and / or Green is expected to make a more effective World Cup contribution than would Donovan.

Npw it's the players' turn? Sure -- but don't take your best player of all time.

@ ClearWindow — If you imply that Donovan isn't "a real goal scorer," you're making an argument utterly at odds with a mountain of evidence. Indeed, Donovan is a landmark player in U.S. soccer because he's really our first men's player in the modern era who doesn't just score goals here and there, but is truly a "goal scorer."

And he's scored in a remarkable variety of ways. Your disparagement-by-faint-praise of his knack for scoring on "rebounds" and "lucky breaks" is unpersuasive for several reasons. To the extent it disdains a player's capacity to seize opportunities that flash before him . . . well, you go right ahead and leave that talent off your dream team. •My• ideal side won't be able to get enough of it!

More importantly, however, your notion that Donovan has substantially made a career on "lucky breaks" simply doesn't bear close scrutiny. I can imagine a marginal player building a glitzy reputation with a few spectacular goals, somehow pulled out of unlikely situations, and see one might argue that there's more luck than substance there. But it doesn't wash with a player who's consistently scored remarkable goals over so many years.

The old saw is, "You make your own luck." As somebody who was successful in competitive athletics at a fairly high level for many years, I know just how true that is. Good for Donovan if he has •looked• lucky; those who truly understand athletics have no doubt about the hard work and skill that have created that appearance.

— Brian
@Brian: As Branch Rickey memorably said: "Luck is the residue of design."

Given LD's experience, his showing up and playing large in key WC moments,  the US absolutely needs his on field leadership in Group G.  Ok, so maybe Julian Green has better speed and endurance, but is that where the goals are going to come from in tough moments?  Smells like 1998.

The press can't ask a coach why he didn't play a player who isn't there, so on that score there will be one less distraction in Brazil. I don't think Klinsmann has ever been completely sold on Donovan, all his acknowledged skill and achievements notwithstanding. I he always questioned Donovan's failure to really do everything he could to succeed in Germany and his preference to spend his career in the relative comfort of MLS and Los Angeles. The handwriting has been on the wall since Landon's magical mystery tour to Cambodia and I further suspect that their relationship has been difficult, for reasons known only to them, since Donovan's failed loan experiment at Bayern under Jürgen. I suspect Jürgen decided to replace Donovan with the future-Julian Green-and a hungry, in form veteran with no baggage-Wondolowski. At least Landon can console himself in the knowledge that it took two players to replace him. He's had a great career and deserves all the accolades that are coming his way. And he is, so far, handling this with class. Whether this is a mistake by Klinsmann we will never know. Sooner or later every player is cut or dropped or felled by injury. And someone else steps in. As they say in Italy, "When the Pope dies they make another one". Thank you, and Good Luck, Landon.
Klinsmann has the experience of hoisting the trophy above his head!

@Brian:" I'll put the same question to you that I put to @clear window:
Who do you see Klinsi picking for the back four, and who do you think he'll pick to partner Bradley in the middle?

Notwithstanding the history between Klinsman and Donovan the last couple years, I'm still surprised at this — especially in light of who's left on the squad . . . for example, Beasley and Beckerman. I don't have anything against those two, and yeah, I know Beasley's listed as a defender, but there has to be a level at which the decision reflects a simple question: are we taking our 23 best players, period?

I still think Donovan's versatility is the principal factor, distinguishing him from his competitors, that would have made me hesitant to go to Brazil without him. And I agree that sentiment grounded in accomplishments of years past constitutes no claim to a spot on the roster — but history tells you things that may not show up in the organization's numbers-crunching, and experience has a value that defies quantification. When all is said and done, Donovan so often came up big for his country in big games . . . and I'm •far• from convinced that the rest of this U.S. squad has that quality in such abundance that we can afford to toss any of it away so casually.

If the U.S. can advance from this brutal group, then most observers will shrug off this decision, and give Klinsman well-deserved credit. But for now, we're beset by the deep anxiety that Coach K may have selected a team that could advance from this group four •years• from now . . . .

— Brian

Always been a fan of Donovan, even when he deserted the Earthquakes. But, in watching him play he seems less than what he was. The Coach had to make a choice and so no Donovan. I really don't get the comments about how this is such a bad move. This team is facing a tough task and sentiment and history are not much help against such quality opponents. Open competition and he didn't make it, but he had a great run.

I was hoping to see the this headline somewhere: "Jürgen Finally Dumps Donovan, Names Five Germans, a Norwegian and an Icelander to USA World Cup Team, Latin Players MIA". And for the purposes of this discussion I am excluding central defenders with Hispanic names.

Three reasons why JK should have picked him, even if he gets little or no soccer. One, Donovan is a fan favorite, and US soccer can use as many fans as it can get & high ratings. Two, his experience and reputation will lift the squad. Three, its giving everyone a reason to JK bash, which the team doesnt need. Witness the NYT article headline.

Surely you take him as a reserve. Or a tourist.

I hope we are all wrong about this, JK. Brave decision.
Your standards are quite high if you think reaching the semi-finals of the World Cup does not equate to good luck as a coach.

Klinsmann has never had much luck as a coach - yeah he's done ok with the US program - and with a decision like this its apparent why. Donovan is a winner and winner's rise to the occasion - klinsmann should know this. If the US even draws one game in the group it will be an accomplishment - with LD they had a chance to do that.

Altidore will exit this Cup with assists, not goals. Both Aron and Wondo will poach off of him.

This decision sets up some very interesting possibilities up front.

We advance.
@Clear: Always admire your optimism. Who do you see starting on the back line, and who do you see as JK picking to partner with Bradley?

So Altidore makes the team but not Landon?

Way to go, Jurgen.

The US won't advance out of their group.
Sure, but Brad Davis is four months older than Donovan. And Brad Davis is no Donovan.

Um, Ronaldinho was on the 2002 World Champions. Do you not remember his astonishing long, long free kick from the touch line that sailed over David Seaman's head in the QF against England?

"32 is basically ancient?" I guess we'll see how Germany does with 36 year old Mirko Klose, Cote D'Ivoire with Didier Drogba, Ghana against us with Michael Essien AND Sulley Muntari, England with both Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard, and Italy with Gigi Buffon (OK, he's a goalkeeper). And naming those players came right off the top of my head.Players are better conditioned than ever before in history, and Pele, talked out of international retirement at 29 to play in HIS fourth World Cup, led the greatest World Cup winning team ever.
I'm not a great Donovan fan, but this one's a head scratcher, and comes fraught with risk for Klinsi. But I don't think it will make a difference. When I look at the potential back fours and partners for Michal Bradley, I'm not sanguine.
Thanks for the explanation asdga.

I don't have my finger on the pulse of soccer, but I get the feeling that 32 is basically ancient...

Every four years at the world cup, the only time I really pay attention to soccer, I am introduced to one or two Brazilians who are proclaimed to be huge international superstars. And then four years later? They are nowhere to be found, and it's a whole new crop. In 2002 it was Ronaldo... but then in 2006 (when he was 30), he may have still been on the team but it was all about a new guy, a rather ugly chap named Ronaldinho. Ok, I though I could get used to him as the new ticket. But then come 2010 (when Ronaldinho was 30), he wasn't even on the team! Instead, it was all about "Kaka," and all the announcers are talking about him like he's always been the Derek Jeter of the Brazilian team, even though this was the first I had ever heard of him. And lo and behold... it's 2014 and "Kaka" (now 32) is nowhere to be found (except for the dustbin of Wikipedia). To this year's Brazilian sensation Neymar, all I can say is this: memento mori.
By your logic, we should have named Eric Wynalda to the team
Regardless of the reasons why he was not selected, his experience in the world cup would definitely come into play.
Totally agree.  He usually plays poorly. the BEST he can muster is mediocre.
Right. Great reply to this forum. Employed by USSF are you?
A good decision. Less knowledgeable fans are up in arms, but those who truly understand the game are neither surprised nor disappointed.

I hope you are right Chalermraj. But they are better organized and better armed than in 2010. They threw a grenade at the Monument. They will grow new heads. And they will hear all the UN people condemning the coup and take the news to Issan.

This all seems like high-tech cops and robbers and a lot of fun (and full employment) for the video game generation.

I just hope that the only negative consequence is the loss of some profits to multi-national corporations. But I suspect that the real game is disruption of or defense of electrical, transportation, water grids and other more significant utilities that are increasingly dependent on computer technology and the internet.
What is the US government afraid of? This is the stuff of a totalitarian nightmares with the willing functionaries doing their bidding. This is madness that should not be allowed to continue.
